data.event: The primary settlement in town, where 1,094 people resided at the 2010 census, is defined as the Marlborough census-designated place (CDP) and is located at the junction of New Hampshire routes 101 and 124.
First granted as Monadnock No. 5 in 1752 by Governor Benning Wentworth, this was one of the fort towns originally known only by a number.
Lots were drawn in 1762 and first settled two years later.
Lots were drawn in 1762 and first settled two years later.
The town was at one time called Oxford, then New Marlborough, but was incorporated in 1776 as Marlborough.
Land was set off in 1815 to create the town of Troy.
